questions.question: A villager was assaulted by 4-5 people & brought to hospital in serious condition. His dying declaration was being taken in hospital. What is correct regarding this process?

options.D: Oath is compulsory before recording the statement

questions.explanation: exceptional cases, when a Magistrate is unavailable and death is imminent, a doctor or even a police officer may record the statement Dying Declaration vs Dying Deposition Feature Dying Declaration Dying Deposition Recorder Anyone—Magistrate/doctor/village headman/police/any member of the public Always recorded by a Magistrate Oath (Option D) Not required Must be taken Accused or his counsel Not present Always present Cross-examination Not done Done Legal value Comparatively less Much more Admissibility if declarant survives Not admitted, but has corroborative value Fully admitted Nature Merely recording of statement Complete court procedure Type of evidence Documentary Oral Status in India Followed Not followed Leading Qs (Option C) Not Permitted Permitted Doctor can record the statement (Option B): Not ideal. A doctor can record the dying declaration only if a Magistrate is unavailable and death is imminent. However, the Magistrate is the preferred authority for legal validity. Reference: Gautam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology 3rd Edition Page 48, 49

questions.question: A married female died in unnatural condition within 3 years of marriage. Her father filed a report to police and inquiry will be done under which section?
questions.explanation: mandatory under Section 176 CrPC (or Section 196 BNSS) . This ensures a thorough and impartial investigation, especially when foul play, suicide, or dowry-related violence is suspected. In India, there are two types of inquests: police inquest and magistrate inquest. 1. Police Inquest (Section 194, BNSS) Most common type of inquest in India. Conducted by a police officer , generally not below the rank of Head Constable . The police officer, upon receiving information about the unnatural death, visits the site. ↓ Involves two or more witnesses from the local area, called panchas , to assist in the investigation. The report is referred to as a panchnama . ↓ If the cause of death appears to be accidental or non-suspicious, the body is handed over to the family for funeral proceedings. ↓ In case of suspicious circumstances , the police officer forwards the body for a postmortem to a certified medical officer and sends the report to the Magistrate . 2. Magistrate Inquest (Section 196, BNSS) Conducted by an Executive Magistrate , or Judicial Magistrate . It's mandatory in specific circumstances, including: Death, the disappearance of a person, or alleged rape in police custody or any custody authorized by the court Deaths due to police firing Deaths in jail Deaths of women within 7 years of marriage if, Commits suicide In any circumstances raising a reasonable suspicion that some other person committed an offence Any relative of the woman has made a request on this behalf There is any doubt regarding the cause of death Deaths where there's suspicion of rape before death Deaths with suspicion of foul play or where a relative of the deceased has made a request Also conducted if the case is referred by police due to suspicion arising during their investigation An inquiry by a Judicial Magistrate or Metropolitan Magistrate is required in instances of custodial death, disappearance, or custodial rape where foul play is suspected or there are allegations of an offense. In all other situations, the inquiry can be conducted by an Executive Magistrate. The magistrate is responsible for forwarding the body for postmortem examination to a Civil Surgeon or another authorized doctor within 24 hours of the death. Differences Between Police and Magistrate Inquests: Feature Police Inquest Magistrate Inquest Conducted by Police officer Magistrate (DM, SDM, Judicial, or Executive Magistrate) Involvement of witnesses Requires signatures of panchas Does not require witness signatures Witness statements Admissible in court Not admissible in court Can order arrest No, but can arrest in cognizable offenses Can issue arrest warrants Exhumation Cannot order exhumation Can order exhumation of a body Autopsy orders Sends bodies for autopsy indiscriminately Orders autopsy only when necessary Forensic analysis Cannot order chemical analysis of viscera Can order chemical analysis Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page. 43, 44. The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, K S Narayan Reddy, OP Murty, 35th Edition, Page. 5, 6. https://bprd.nic.in/uploads/pdf/COMPARISON%20SUMMARY%20BNS%20to%20IPC%20.pdf

questions.question: Who order the autopsy in case of RTA?
questions.explanation: ordering an autopsy to determine the cause of death. This is part of their duty to investigate the circumstances surrounding the death and to ensure proper legal procedures are followed. The police will request an autopsy if there is a need to understand the cause of death more clearly or if it is required for legal reasons. Incorrect Options: Option A - Forensic expert: A forensic expert conducts the autopsy but does not order it. The role of the forensic expert is to perform the examination and provide a report based on their findings. Option C - Lawyer: A lawyer may request an autopsy as part of legal proceedings, but they do not have the authority to order an autopsy in cases of RTA. Their role is generally more related to the legal representation of the parties involved. Option D - Forensic doctor: Similar to the forensic expert, the forensic doctor performs the autopsy but does not order it. The forensic doctor provides medical expertise in the examination and interpretation of findings.

questions.question: A forensic expert received a summons from the district court to record his evidence in a criminal case, but two days prior, he already received a summons for a civil case in the same district court for the same date. What should the doctor do?

options.B: Attend the court for which the summons came first.
options.C: Attend the court for the criminal case.

questions.explanation: forensic expert must attend the criminal case and inform the civil court about the conflict, requesting a rescheduled date. Ignoring a court summons can lead to legal consequences, so prioritizing the criminal case is mandatory. Summons/Subpoena: A subpoena is a legal order mandating a witness to appear before a court on a specific date, time, and location to provide testimony or evidence, under penalty. A subpoena is issued by the court in writing, signed by the presiding officer, and carries the court's official seal (Sec. 63 BNSS) . Delivered to the witness by a police officer, court official, or public servant. The witness must sign and return a duplicate copy of the subpoena to acknowledge receipt (Sec. 64 BNSS). Types of Subpoenas Subpoena duces tecum : The witness is required to bring specific documents or items to the court (e.g., medico-legal reports or postmortem findings). For expert witness. Subpoena ad testificandum : The witness is required to appear in court to provide oral testimony. For common witnesses. Punishment for Failing to Comply with a Subpoena/Summons: 1. Civil Cases: The witness may be ordered to pay damages for failing to attend court. This involves compensation for the inconvenience caused to the parties involved in the case. 2. Criminal Cases: If a witness fails to appear in court without a justified reason, the following actions can be taken: Under 63 – 71 BNSS , the court may issue a notice to the witness to explain their absence. The court may issue notice under Section 389, BNSS and after hearing the witness, if it finds that the witness neglected to attend the court without a justified reason, may punish him under Section 208 and 209, BNS , and sentence him/her to: A fine (Rs.1000/-), OR Imprisonment (6 months), OR Both fine and imprisonment. Also, the Court may issue bailable or non-bailable warrants to secure the presence of the witness ( S.206 to 209, BNS and S.90, BNSS ). Prioritization of Summons: Criminal vs. Civil Courts : If a witness is summoned by both criminal and civil courts for the same day, they must attend the criminal court , which takes precedence. Higher vs. Lower Courts : When summoned by two courts of the same jurisdiction (e.g., civil or criminal), the witness must attend the higher court first. Multiple Summons : If the witness receives multiple summonses from the same type of court, they should attend the court that issued the first summons and notify the other. Inform both courts and wait (Option A): While informing both courts is a good step, simply waiting without attending either court is not advisable, as it could lead to legal consequences. Attend the court for which the summons came first (Option B): The order in which the summons were received does not determine priority. The nature of the case (criminal vs. civil) takes precedence. Do not attend either court (Option D): Ignoring court summons can result in contempt of court or other legal penalties. Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, K S Narayan Reddy, OP Murty, 35th Edition, Page. 7. Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page. 47, 48 https://prsindia.org/files/bills_acts/bills_parliament/2023/Bharatiya_Nagarik_Suraksha_Sanhita,_2023.pdf

questions.question: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her mother with a complaint of abdominal pain. The patient's urine pregnancy test (UPT) is positive. What should be the first step by you as a medical officer?

options.C: Take consent from the patient's mother

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Inform the police Explanation: In cases involving minors with a positive pregnancy test, suspicion of sexual assault or abuse must be considered. The first step is to notify the police , as per the Protection of Children from Sexual Offenses (POCSO) Act, which mandates mandatory reporting of such cases to protect the child and initiate an investigation. Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act Enacted in 2012, it is law in India designed to protect children under the age of 18 from sexual abuse, sexual harassment, and pornography. Key Features of the POCSO Act: Gender-neutral law It covers penetrative and non-penetrative assault, sexual harassment, and use of children for pornography Burden of proof is on the accused, unlike many other criminal laws where the burden is on the prosecution Mandatory reporting by adults and failure to do so can be punishable Special courts for the trial of offenses to ensure a child-friendly environment Identity of the victim is to be protected, and the proceedings are to be conducted in camera to prevent exposure Recent Changes and Developments in the POCSO Act: 2019 Amendment Stricter Punishments: Death penalty for aggravated sexual assault against children The minimum punishment for penetrative sexual assault increased to 10 years, and for aggravated penetrative sexual assault increased to 20 years, with the possibility of life imprisonment or death in extreme cases. Fast-track Courts to ensure swift disposal of POCSO cases, given the backlog of pending cases. Clarifications on ‘Touch’ and Sexual Intent: The intent behind physical contact is crucial in determining whether it qualifies as an offense under POCSO. Digital Crimes Against Children: Provisions related to the use of children for pornographic and online exploitation purposes have been emphasized with stricter penalties. Reference: https://bnblegal.com/bareact/the-protection-of-children-from-sexual-offences-amendment-act-2019/

questions.question: The authority who investigates the death of a 14-year-old girl who was abducted by a man and subsequently died while in police custody will be?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Judicial magistrate Explanation:As per Section 176 CrPC (Code of Criminal Procedure, India), when a person dies in police custody or under suspicious circumstances, the investigation must be conducted by a Judicial Magistrate. Key Reasons: Judicial Magistrate ensures an impartial and independent inquiry. Mandatory for cases involving: Death in police custody. Death of minors under suspicious circumstances. Death due to abduction or unnatural causes. Coroner (Option A): Outdated in India, previously investigated unnatural deaths. Police (Option B): Cannot investigate deaths occurring in their custody independently due to conflict of interest. Medical Examiner (Option C): Conducts autopsies but does not have legal authority for formal investigation. Reference: Inquest

questions.question: The first-hand knowledge rule is applicable to which of the following?
questions.explanation: personal knowledge rule, is applicable to a common witness. A common witness is an individual who has observed or experienced an event directly and can provide testimony based on their own personal knowledge of the event. The first-hand knowledge rule requires that a witness's testimony be based on facts or information that they themselves have perceived through their own senses Incorrect Options: Option B - Hand writing expert : They rely on their specialized knowledge and training rather than personal observation or direct experience of the events related to the handwriting. Option C - Doctor: A doctor may provide expert testimony based on their professional knowledge and experience rather than personal observation or direct experience of a specific event. Option D - Hostile witness : A hostile witness is a witness who is unwilling or uncooperative in providing testimony.the first-hand knowledge rule is not specifically applicable to hostile witnesses. Reference: Prepladder Notes

options.C: To tell or discuss with colleagues that she is a case of abuse

Option C - To tell or discuss with colleagues that she is a case of abuse : Discussing the case with colleagues can provide additional insights, but it is necessary to gather more information through a comprehensive examination before making any definitive conclusions. questions.question: When an individual commences employment with a second employer , the new employer assumes responsibility for the individual's actions, under which doctrine ?
questions.explanation: the new employer may assume responsibility for their actions under the Borrowed Servant Doctrine. This doctrine applies when an employee is temporarily loaned or "borrowed" by another employer. In such cases, the borrowing employer assumes control over the borrowed employee and becomes responsible for their actions within the scope of their employment during the loaned period. Incorrect Options : Option A - Vicarious liability : Vicarious liability refers to a situation where one person or entity is held responsible for the actions of another person or entity. Option B - Doctrine of negligent choice : The Doctrine of negligent choice refers to a legal principle that holds a party liable for choosing a negligent individual or entity to perform a task. Option C - Contributory negligence : Contributory negligence assigns partial blame to a plaintiff for their own injuries or damages due to their failure to exercise reasonable care. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which section of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) is associated with the penalization of perjury ?
questions.explanation: offense of giving false evidence in a judicial proceeding It specifies that whoever intentionally gives false evidence in any stage of a judicial proceeding, or fabricates false evidence intending it to be used in a judicial proceeding, shall be punished with imprisonment and/or a fine. This section specifically addresses the punishment of perjury, which involves knowingly making false statements while under oath during a court proceeding. Incorrect Options: Option A - Section 191: Section 191 of the IPC deals with the offense of giving false evidence Option B - Section 192 : Section 192 of the IPC relates to the offense of fabricating false evidence. Option D - Section 197: Under Section 197, if a person in an official capacity knowingly issues or signs a false certificate, they can be punished with imprisonment and or a fine. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: What is the responsibility of the doctor in recording the dying declaration of a victim affected by a fire ?

options.B: To record the statement even in the presence of magistrate
options.D: Put the person under oath before declaration

questions.explanation: the doctor is to assess the mental capacity of the person making the statement, also known as "compos mentis." The doctor evaluates whether the person is of sound mind a nd capable of providing a coherent and reliable statement. This assessment helps determine the admissibility and credibility of the dying declaration as evidence in legal proceedings. Incorrect Options: Option B - To record the statement even in the presence of a magistrate : It is not the role of the doctor to record the statement in the presence of a magistrate Option C - Cross-examine the person : Cross-examination is a legal procedure conducted by legal professionals, such as lawyers or prosecutors. It is not the role of the doctor to cross-examine the person giving the dying declaration. Option D - Put the person under oath before declaration: The doctor's role in recording a dying declaration does not involve putting the person under oath. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following statements does not apply during cross-examination in a court of law ?

options.A: Witness is examined by the defense lawyer
options.C: Objective of cross-examination is to weaken case of opponent
options.D: There is no time limit to cross examination

questions.explanation: incorrect statement regarding cross-examination in a court of law. In fact, leading questions are often used during cross-examination to elicit specific information or to challenge the witness's testimony, under section 143 IEA. Therefore, the statement "Leading questions are not allowed" does not apply during cross-examination in a court of law. Incorrect Options: Option A - Witness is examined by the defense lawyer: That statement applies during cross-examination in a court of law. The defense lawyer has the right to cross-examine the witness in order to test their credibility and the reliability of their testimony. Option C - Objective of cross-examination is to weaken case of opponent: The objective of cross-examination is to challenge the credibility, accuracy, and completeness of the witness's testimony, and to weaken the case presented by the opposing party. The cross-examining lawyer aims to extract information that may undermine the witness's testimony or support their own case. Option D - There is no time limit to cross examination: The specific time limits may vary depending on the jurisdiction and the specific rules of the court, but they are generally in place to ensure that the trial proceeds in an efficient and timely manner. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: As an internal medicine consultant at a private clinic , you are handling the case of a patient who has chronic renal disease and needs hemodialysis . You provide dietary and fluid management recommendations and closely monitor the patient. Unfortunately, the patient decides to take ayurvedic supplements and occasionally disregards your instructions without informing you. Consequently, the patient's condition deteriorates, leading to respiratory distress . Subsequently, the patient's attendant files a legal complaint, accusing the doctor of negligence. Which of the following can serve as a defense for the doctor in court ?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Contributory negligence Explanation: Contributory negligence is a valid legal defence in medical negligence cases. It applies when the patient (or their caregiver) fails to follow medical advice or engages in actions that contribute to their own harm , which reduces or nullifies the liability of the doctor. In this case: The doctor gave appropriate care and advice . The patient disregarded medical instructions and used alternative (ayurvedic) therapies . These actions directly contributed to the deterioration of the condition. Indian courts recognize contributory negligence as a valid defense in medical negligence cases. If it is shown that the patient’s non-compliance or independent actions played a role in the adverse outcome, the doctor’s liability can be reduced or even negated Thus, contributory negligence can protect the doctor from full liability. Vicarious liability (Option A): Refers to liability of an employer (e.g., hospital) for the actions of its employee. Does not apply to a private consultant being sued personally. Res Ipsa loquitur (Option B): Means "the thing speaks for itself". Used when negligence is obvious , e.g., leaving a surgical instrument inside the body. In this case, the deterioration was not clearly due to the doctor's action. Therapeutic misadventure (Option C): Refers to an adverse event despite proper therapy , typically unavoidable or rare. Not applicable here as the decline was due to non-compliance , not an unexpected drug reaction or intervention. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5531144/

Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A doctor was summoned as a public witness to appear and record his evidence in court. What is correct about this witness?
questions.explanation: possesses specialized knowledge, skills, or expertise in a particular field that is relevant to the case. In the given scenario, a doctor is summoned as a witness. If the doctor's testimony is related to their medical expertise and is meant to provide insight and explanation to the court on medical matters, then they would be considered an expert witness Incorrect Options: Option A - Oral evidence: Oral evidence refers to the testimony or statements provided by witnesses verbally in court. This option does not accurately describe the scenario in which a doctor is summoned as a witness. The scenario mentioned doesn't specifically emphasize the mode of evidence (oral or written) but focuses on the role of the witness. Option B - Common witness: There is no standard term called "common witness." Witnesses can be categorized based on various factors, but this terminology isn't commonly used. The scenario doesn't provide enough information to suggest that the doctor in question is a "common witness." Option D - Hostile witness: A hostile witness is a term used to describe a witness who is uncooperative or openly antagonistic towards the party that called them to testify. This option is not applicable to the scenario provided, where a doctor is summoned as a public witness to record evidence in court.

questions.question: Medical termination of pregnancy can be done upto 24 weeks in case of?
questions.explanation: of rape victims Incorrect Options: Option A - Fetus malformation : Medical termination of pregnancy can be done beyond 24 weeks if the fetus is found to have severe malformations or abnormalities that are incompatible with life or would result in significant physical or mental challenges for the child. Option B - Minors : Minors generally require parental or guardian consent for medical procedures, including abortion. The laws regarding abortion for minors can vary by country and jurisdiction, but typically there are provisions for involving parents or guardians in the decision-making process. Option C - Contraception failure: Medical termination of pregnancy is not typically allowed solely due to contraception failure. However, if the failure of contraception leads to unwanted pregnancy and the woman's health or life is at risk, abortion might be considered based on medical assessment. Reference: .
